benchmark_details.name: MFC-Bench (Multimodal Fact-Checking Benchmark)
benchmark_details.overview: MFC-Bench is a rigorous benchmark designed to evaluate the factual accuracy of large vision-language models (LVLMs) across three stages of verdict prediction for multimodal fact-checking: Manipulation Classification, Out-of-Context Classification, and Veracity Classification.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a comprehensive evaluation platform for the factual accuracy of LVLMs in multimodal fact-checking tasks.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The current benchmark may not fully capture the complexity of real-world multimodal fact-checking due to the dynamic and context-specific nature of misinformation.

data.source: A mix of diverse datasets specifically designed for multimodal fact-checking.
data.annotation: Human evaluation and automated methods for verifying manipulation techniques.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are computed based on the performance of the LVLMs across different tasks in the benchmark.
methodology.interpretation: A higher F1 Score indicates better performance in correctly identifying facts vs. non-facts.
methodology.baseline_results: Human performance serves as a baseline, significantly outperforming the LVLMs in detection tasks.
methodology.validation: Multiple levels of quality assurance checks and evaluations were performed on the collected data.

targeted_risks.harm: The benchmark aims to prevent the spread of misinformation and enhance the trustworthiness of AI systems.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: All data utilized in this research does not contain any user information from social media and adheres to the terms of datasets used.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: Informed consent was obtained from all human evaluators involved.
